qas.question: When was the first criminal part of copyright law in the U.S. added?
What type of penalty was made for unlawful performances that are willful and for profit?
What did a criminal infringer do to be prosecuted?

answers.text: for the purpose of commercial advantage or private financial gain

qas.question: What must a prosecuter show after the basic elements of infringement?
What is the threshold of the number of copies and the value of the works?
When was the last criminal part of copyright law in the U.S. added?
What type of penalty was made for lawful performances that are willful and for profit?

plausible_answers.text: for the purpose of commercial advantage or private financial gain.

qas.question: What did a criminal infringer not do to be prosecuted?
What mustn't a prosecuter show after the basic elements of infringement?
What isn't the threshold of the number of copies and the value of the works?

context: The first criminal provision in U.S. copyright law was added in <a0_0><b5_0>1897<b5_0/><a0_0/>, which established a <a1_0><b6_0>misdemeanor<b6_0/><a1_0/> penalty for "unlawful performances and representations of copyrighted dramatic and musical compositions" if the violation had been "willful and for profit." Criminal copyright infringement requires that the infringer acted "<a2_0><b7_0>for the purpose of commercial advantage or private financial gain<a2_0/>.<b7_0/>" 17 U.S.C. § 506. To establish criminal liability, the prosecutor must first show the basic elements of copyright infringement: ownership of a valid copyright, and the violation of one or more of the copyright holder's exclusive rights. The government must then establish <a3_0><b8_0>that defendant willfully infringed<b8_0/><a3_0/> or, in other words, possessed the necessary mens rea. Misdemeanor infringement has a <a4_0><b9_0>very low threshold<b9_0/><a4_0/> in terms of number of copies and the value of the infringed works.
